The tool itself would be very usefull...
Where can i get it ? :-)

-----Original Message-----
From: rainsber@... [mailto:rainsber@...]
Sent: donderdag 19 juli 2001 15:55
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Re: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts


I don't like this for unit testing new code; I do like it for unit testing
legacy code that doesn't already have unit tests.

My concern is that people will use this tool to write new code "test-last".
Although it's better than no tests at all, it does not take advantage of
the incidental benefits of test-first: simpler design, ~100% coverage and
so on.

Certainly the tool itself would be very useful; however, I would have to
watch over my developers to make sure they're not using it to write new
code when I expect them to write that code test-first.

J. B. Rainsberger  <rainsber@...>
Commerce Suite Accelerator: Rule Services, IBM Toronto Lab
8200 Warden Av, Office A3-735 [A3/FNB/8200/MKM]
Markham ON   L6G 1C7
905 413-2501 (969-2501)


Vladimir Bossicard <vladimir@...> on 07/18/2001 20:03:00

Please respond to junit@yahoogroups.com

To:   junit@yahoogroups.com
cc:
Subject:  Re: [junit] Re: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts



> Mind if I ask why exactly do you want a empty test method there?

I don't want anything!  It's not an empty method, it's a method that is
currently empty but will be written later.

> What is the difference if you just add the method later?

I just pointed out that if you really want an empty method (with no
assertion -> reported as successfull by JUnit) you must add some note to
not forget to write the code.  If you don't I'm sure you'll forget at the
end of the project that you still have somewhere (dude, where's my empty
method?) code to write.

If you declare your method "_notImplemented" :
1) you can only define one unimplemented method per TestCase
2) you don't code anything meaningfull.  If you want to write a template,
the method's name should at least mean something (such as
"testThrowExceptionA"...).

I imagine a tool that parses your classes and generates a specific TestCase
class with methods to test your public methods?  Let's say: you have a
method that can throw exceptions A, B or C, your generated file will have 3
methods (testThrowA, testThrowB, testThrowC...) with (almost) empty bodies.
Does it make sense?

BTW anyone thinks that it is a good idea? (the tool is IDE independant of
course).

-Vladimir
